content.description: Climb the prominent, flaring dihedral at the right edge of the face. Tt seems impossible for the first couple of tries due to the bulging/sloping right side and the non-positive holds on the left.
content.location: This lies on the right, prominent corner of K Wall.

content.description: Tensile Strength climbs the line of old quarter inch bolts right of Pins.  The first 3/4 of the climb is fun, fairly easy climbing.  Climb a thin crack to a flake that trends up and left.  Follow the sloping holds along the flake until you can pull up and stand on top of it.  The crux is the blank section above.  Strenuous moves on small nubbins and edges lead to the top.
content.protection: 6 bolts.Â Various anchors located along the top of the wall.
content.location: It lies about eight feet right of Pins, just left of an angling, left-facing corner at ground level.

content.description:
This is a much better climb than it appears from the ground. Start up Pins (5.9) until you hit the left-angling seam.  You can hand traverse here with a bad feet or climb Pins slightly higher and have the seam for feet.  Mantle onto a good ledge and take a good rest before the crux.  From here, follow a thin seam straight up using small edges, side pulls, and a few deceptive holds in the seam.  I found the climbing to be quite sequency, technical and way harder than the surrounding climbs.  I was surprised that I was still on the wall most of the time. 

  Eventually you can reach some bigger holds out right from the seam.  Have a good rest then grab a hidden jug and fire through some small edges and a fun layback to the top. 

  On first effort, I felt this climb to be 11-, but it might just 10+ though Boston Rocks gives it grade of 10.  Until you figure out the beta, it feels desperate.  Lots of holds are hard to see or difficult to determine if they are any good until your hand is on them. 

  Definitely give it a try if you set up a rope for Pins or Outside Corner.
content.protection:
Best to toprope with bolts at top for anchor. 

  Protection is good for the first third starting up Pins up through the diagonal traverse.  Above here, the protection is poor taking maybe microstoppers in the seam and possibly small cams in the pods after the crux.  Final third is better taking mostly small stuff here, but you may not even bother throwing any in as the holds improve.
content.location: This is on the face right of the obvious, sharp arete as you enter The Quarries.  It shares a start with Pins.

content.description: Start in a wide, right-leaning crack, with a small seam that leads up to the left.  Climb past a left-angling crack (The Power of Positive Thinking, 10) to a small pod on the right side of the crack about 1/2 way up.  Reach for a good, right-facing, side pull and pull up through the blank face (crux).  The second difficulty is climbing though the small edges with poor feet near the top.
content.protection: Small gear if leading, belay/TR anchors on top.
content.location: This is located about eight feet right of Outside Corner.

content.description: This is a fun climb and popular lead.  There are a couple of options for the start: you can either climb the outside corner to a stance and then step right, or climb the blocky face to the right that is in direct line with the upper part of the climb.  Continue climbing to the right of the arete to a small ledge just below the crux at about 3/4 of the way up.  The crux is an awkward right leaning layback to a decent crack.  Reach high and work your feet up the smooth surface.  There are a couple of old pins on the route.  Like most of the climbs here, Outside Corner felt stiff for the grade.  Photo.
content.protection: If leading, bring a light rack with small to medium gear and a couple draws to clip the old pins.  If TR'ing, anchor off bolts and the strange assortment of rebar and hooks at the top.
content.location: This is located on the far left side of K Wall and climbs just to the right of the obvious arete.

content.description: Start in the wide crack to right of Tensile Strength, then climb the thin cracks above.
content.location: This is the obvious wide crack to the right of Tensile Strength.

content.description: Face climb between Pins and Tensile Strength.
content.location: Start just to the right of the Pins/Power of Positive Thinking crack.

content.description:
There is lots of loose rock above the right side of this face. To its left is the L Face. The climbing here was aesthetic in some ways and lends the sense you are climbing something a bit bigger. Additional graffitti has detracted from the ambience. With the big fill-in, it is much easier to access the climbing here. 200 feet of dirt sure helps. No dangling above water anymore.Be careful if you use the installed bolts when setting up a toprope. Some of the bolts are not secure. 

L->R:A.Outside Corner, 8, 1p, 50', gear or TR, nice shot.B1. The Power Of Positive Thinking, 10, 55'. lead photoB2C. Pins, 9, 1p, 50', TR.C. Needles, 10, 1p, 50', TR.D1. Tensile Strength, 10-, 1p, 50', TR.D2. Ironmonger, A2.E. Bombay, 10+, 1p, 50', TR.F. Thunderstorm, 10 or V1-2, 20', TR or pad.G. Static Cling, 10-.
